Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ecological costs of tri-trophic plant defenses against herbivores

The ecological costs of correlated selection on multiple defenses may have the potential to constrain plant evolution. The proposed work will use comparative and experimental methods to address questions about costs of defense through: (1) Examining how selection for growth has affected the retention and expression of herbivore-induced plant volatiles, an indirect defense of plants which attracts the natural enemies of herbivores, and (2) Determining the relationship among multiple defense traits. There are several examples of herbivore-induced plant volatile loss in plants, primarily in agricultural crops, which have undergone selective breeding for increased yield. It is unlikely that herbivore-induced plant volatiles have undergone direct selection, so their loss suggests that volatile production is costly and trades off with growth or other traits under selection. Because of this, agricultural crop variation in herbivore-induced volatile production is ideal for examining allocation and ecological costs of defenses.

Plant primary producers are a vital tool against the global threats of disease, climate change, and food supply insecurity. It is imperative to understand how selection pressures influence plant traits and the effects of those traits on important biological interactions. The proposed research examines the ecological costs of conventional breeding practices on agriculturally important species interactions. Some applications from this work include informing land managers and plant breeders about potential strategies to reduce herbivore damage levels and the need for pesticides. This work will have educational benefits: the PI will mentor undergraduate and graduate students and will participate in K-12 outreach activities. Increased participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields will be accomplished through undergraduate research involvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major experimental goals of this project were to determine ecological and evolutionary costs of: 1) plant defenses against herbivores and 2) other species interactions, using comparisons among a domesticated crop (tomato) and its wild relatives. Additional goals included providing mentoring and training opportunities for underrepresented groups in STEM fields.  

Experimental activities included the completion of a large scale field experiment (Purdue University) with 30 cultivars of domesticated tomatoes and 6 species of wild tomato relatives, with data collected on plant tolerance and resistance to herbivores. Additional greenhouse experiments examining differences among crop tomatoes, their wild relatives, and intermediate tomato landraces, were conducted to examine the effects of crop domestication on higher trophic levels (parasitoids and predators) and plant-soil feedbacks. Project activities included collaborative research and project development with postdoctoral and visiting scientists, faculty, and undergraduate and graduate students.

Experimental results demonstrated that the domestication of tomato has reduced its ability to defend against insect pests, especially compared to its wild relatives (Li et al. 2018). Moreover, it was found that crop tomatoes were less effective than wild relatives at attracting insect natural enemies that function as plant defense against herbivores (Li et al. 2018). Combined with these ecological effects aboveground, project results showed that the effects of the soil microbial community differed between wild and domesticated plants, with negative plant-soil feedbacks greater for crop versus wild tomato relatives (Carrillo et al. 2019). In addition to the direct effects on plants, these results indicated that plant-soil interactions can have legacy effects on higher trophic levels, specifically natural enemy attraction (Carrillo et al. 2019).

Three papers, with two student co-authors (indicated by *), have been published related to the project:

Carrillo, J., Ingwell, L., Li, X.*, and I. Kaplan. (2019) Domesticated tomatoes are more vulnerable to negative plant-soil feedbacks than their wild relatives, Journal of Ecology, https://doi.org/10.1111/1365-2745.13157 

Li, X.*, Garvey, M.*, Kaplan, I., Li, B., and J. Carrillo. (2018) Domestication of tomato has reduced the attraction of herbivore natural enemies to pest-damaged plants, Agricultural & Forest Entomology, 20(3): 390-401, https://doi.org/10.1111/afe.12271

Kaplan, I., Carrillo, J., Garvey, M.* and P. Ode. (2016) Indirect plant-parasitoid interactions mediated by changes in herbivore physiology, Current Opinion in Insect Science, 14:112-119, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cois.2016.03.004
